thread.title: Westpac's sale of Vanuatu and Solomons banks scaled back
thread.title_full: Westpac's sale of Vanuatu and Solomons banks scaled back

title: Westpac's sale of Vanuatu and Solomons banks scaled back
text:
Westpac will not sell its Vanuatu business after Cyclone Pam in March, which left debris scattered across Port Vila. Photo: UNICEF Pacific
Westpac's plans to sell its banks in Vanuatu and the Solomon Islands have been put on hold after discussions with regulators in each country prevented deals from going ahead.
Six months ago, Westpac announced it had struck an agreement to sell banks in Samoa, the Cook Islands, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and Tonga to the Bank of South Pacific Ltd (BSP) for $125 million.
But on Tuesday it said the sales in Vanuatu and Solomon Islands would not go ahead for now, and $91 million had been raised instead of $125 million.
The bank said it would not sell the Vanuatu business "at this time" because the Reserve Bank of Vanuatu determined it was not the time for a change in bank operators after the impact of Cyclone Pam.
Advertisement The Pacific Island nation was devastated by the cyclone in March, one of the worst to ever hit the region.
"Westpac will continue to support Vanuatu through its recovery process, and it will be business as usual for our customers and employees," the bank said.
It also said the sale of the Solomon Islands business would not proceed "at this time", as Westpac and the buyer BSP were still in talks with the Central Bank of Solomon Islands about regulatory approvals.
Westpac is keeping its banks in Fiji, viewed as a growth market, and Papua New Guinea.
